I don't see anything that suggests that there will be any EU member state besides the UK setting a date for a referendum on leaving the EU or eurozone prior to the end of the year.  On issues like this which seem stable in the short term, I sometimes like to ask myself a similar question, like:  what EU member state will be the first to set a date for a referendum on leaving the EU or the eurozone?  What do you think?   Off the top of my head I'm thinking it might be Poland because it seems to be chaffing under EU rules and because the open borders rules has caused something of a brain-drain.   Brexit has made me aware of the pitfalls of open borders and unlimited immigration.  Not only does there seem to be a maximum threshold in all human organizations for acceptance of "others",  before "natives" begin to feel threatened and start a backlash, but there has to be resentment on the other side of the fence:  in countries which are experiencing a brain-drain.  A local young gal I know well just returned from spending a year in Bulgaria.  She tells me that every kid in high school with anything at all on the ball in Bulgaria wants desperately to leave Bulgaria as soon as possible.  I'm wondering how most of those young people will feel when circumstances result in them never being able to do so, while some of their friends do, and do spectacularly (or report that they are!). @smitch15, @see, @LukaszK, @ikresnak, @Wildwood2000, @carelesscustomer, @pietrokc, @ccorcoran223, @WBHumanoid, @OttoRenner, @nonplus, @3V_Money

I have to ask what the probability is of a nation leaving the EU, and especially leave before 1 Jan 2020?
For motivation, I looked towards stronger countries like France or Germany who may want to leave in the future because they are carrying weaker states. However, I do not see strong enough motivation for such a decision at this point in time. 
Most countries bar a few, gain more from being part of the EU than they would if they exit. 
Poland has a political party posturing for a referendum, but it is not a view supported by the leading party. The PiS, however, do have support from other right-leaning parties, so it is possible they gain enough support to force a referendum, but again I find it unlikely before the close of 2019.  Italy is one of the more successfull of the EU countries but is the most unstable of the top states. I believe they, like many other member states, are watching the UK's Brexit carefully and weighing out the financial benefits of an exit. 
Once the UK has exited, I believe there will be a cooling off period as other states observe and calculate, it will not be a knee-jerk reaction, it will be a long protracted thought proccess before another country pulls the trigger on Article 50.  My low prediction is therefore based on the unlikely possibility of a member state having sufficient motivation to want to leave the EU before 1 Jan 2020. 
My prediction would be comlelty different if the 'date before' was 1 Jan 2021.

Till 2006 there have been 3 referenda that fit the type in the EU/EC in a total of 705 years of membership, giving a baseline of 1/705 chance per country per year to do such a referendum (plus a roughly identical probability of setting a referendum, as this is required to do it). This will give a 3% probability, yet this is probably a overestimation for several reasons: 2 referenda happened in the same country (UK) and the Greenland one is sort of a particular case, which means that there are correlations. Besides, probably there are at most a handful of countries in which an exit from the EU has appeared in the public debate with a remote semblance of seriousness (but this could be double counting on the probability already estimated of 1/705 per year and per country). Probably a 1% is closer to the mark, and this 1% is probably already an overestimation.

Unlikely. First, most countries are too wrapped up in figuring out how to deal with brexit itself. Finally, genuine split candidates such as Hungary and Poland benefit far too much from EU membership to risk leaving (their governments will not be willing to go that far).

There is to my knowledge currently no coalition in any other state which would be able to initiate any such move.   This situation may change considerably if Brexit occurs on 31 October. If Brexit is defeated or deferred it might be expected that other interested parties will either abandon the Exit cause or wait until the outcome of Brexit is clearer. If, however, Brexit occurs on 31 October, opposition Groups in other states (especially League in Italy) might be emboldened to make a move for political advantage.  However, they would need to have the secured sufficient legislative power to do so.  (Established parties have little interest in promoting such a referendum and the logistics of arranging one between now (27 August 2019) and 1 January 2020 suggest that the probability of this occurring with a change of current government is near zero.) Thus, at this point only the Italian League seems to have both the motivation and the plausible capacity to do this and probably only if Brexit is successful. Assigning a 60% probability to Brexit (see Brexit question) on of before 31 October, the following probabilities might be assigned: 60% * 30% League will win sufficient power in Italy and pursue referendum date by 1-1-2020 = 18%
60% * 5% some other member state will be willing and able to organise a date between 31-10-19 and 1-1-20 = 3% Total 21% Gut feeling:  it won't happen

None of the current governments of the 27 remaining EU member states is promoting to leave the EU. 
Few national elections are set to take place in 2019: Only Italy, Austria, Portugal and Poland will elect a new parliament. No mayor party in these countries has pledged a referendum in their election manifesto.
Potential snap elections in other countries of the EU have a lead time of at least two months. It is highly unlikely that a new government will be in place before the end of the year.
In summary, it can be said that there is no Eurosceptical government or parliamentary majority in sight in any of the 27 other EU countries.

UK called referendum to Leave twice. Its entry, however, was late for major nation and fraught with difficulties (initial attempts vetoed). Greenland left the Union but entered when it was still under Denmark and the region had voted against entry. Catalyst for exit was independence. Base rate is between 4.5% and 7%, given how rarely a Leave referendum has been called, and in the context of the long history and number of countries. Countries in the Eurozone are highly unlikely to leave - no clause that allows for this and it would be far too costly. Remaining countries are likely to have been strongly discouraged by the 'Brexit' ordeal and would want to see how that pans out before thinking of Leaving. All but one of these are trying to converge towards an entry into Eurozone.  Likely catalyst for a Leave referendum would be a region gaining independence (e.g. Catalonia); UK leaves and changes cost-benefit dynamic for remaining countries (e.g. Denmark); or a Eurosceptic party or coalition gains a significant ruling majority. All of this is unlikely to play out before year's end.

It is possible that another EU member state besides the UK will set a date for a referendum on leaving the EU, however, I find it unlikely. There has been growing discussion among certain EU member states such as Italy, Poland, Greece, Hungary, etc about the possibility of leaving. It appears that these discussions largely revolve more nationalistic sentiments in which states wanted autonomy to make their own decisions about what is best for their state politically and economically. A major driving force has been the influx of migrants from the MENA region settling in EU states which has caused a backlash from EU member states wishing to have more control over their territorial borders. However, despite these discussions and sometimes threats to leave, it would not be in the best interest for most if any EU member states to leave at this moment. As we are witnessing with Brexit it has been a divisive and difficult process to disentangle a state from the EU as a large and still maintain a mutually beneficial relationship enjoyed while an EU member state. Leaving the EU for states like Poland or Hungary would not be a major loss for the EU as a whole because they are not a substantial contributer to the EU as a whole, however, they would greatly lose out in the process by foregoing many of the economic and political benefits they have enjoyed as an EU member state. Therefore, I think the rhetoric on leaving the EU will continue but it will be unlikely to produce any implementation of a referendum to leave the EU in any other state other than the UK.

With all of the issues Britain has faced trying to leave the European Union, and the lengthy timelines, it appears to be in the best interest of other member states to postpone any actual leave-taking until the initial bugs are hammered out by the proverbial guinea pig.  That being said,  a referendum is far from a concrete decision and with the current downward trends facing the EU, some members may seek a slight head start in the direction of exiting to be at the front of the line if anything were to start crumbling.

Overall, it seems that the overwhelming majority of EU member states want to remain within the EU to some degree. Even with increasingly more right-wing/Euro-skeptic political influence on several member states, such as Italy or Poland, many would rather seek reform to the current EU structure over outright departure from the EU. This is mostly as a result of the constant struggle the United Kingdom has been dealing with since the results of their membership referendum in 2016: my assumption is that most ruling bodies would rather avoid this altogether. That being said, the question is asking if a referendum would be scheduled, which does not necessarily mean an outright departure. However, I believe the same reasonings for member nations to remain are why they will steer-away from holding a referrendum. Therefore, I think it's very unlikely that an EU member state will schedule a membership referendum before the end of the year.

Differences over Brexit have strained the United Kingdom. Scotland and Northern Ireland voted to stay in the EU in a 2016 referendum, while Wales and England vote to leave.  https://globalnews.ca/news/5197357/scotland-independence-referendum-vote-to-leave-uk/.  The European Union - often known as the EU - is an economic and political partnership involving 28 European countries. It began after World War Two to foster economic co-operation, with the idea that countries which trade together were more likely to avoid going to war with each other.  As things stand, the UK is due to leave the European Union at 23:00 GMT on 31 October 2019.  Leaving the UK might present some hurdles- but it does not lead to complete isolation as some in the media imply.  The World Trade Organization sets rules for countries that don't have free trade deals with each other, including tariffs - the taxes charged on the import of goods. Without an agreement on trade, the UK would trade with the EU under World Trade Organization rules. https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-32810887.  There is a debate to which countries are considered the most likely to leave the EU next.  Like Britain in the EU, Denmark has constantly demanded exceptions from EU law.  Czech elections in October were characterized by the rise of the far-right, anti-European Freedom and Direct Democracy party, who won 22 seats, entering parliament for the first time.  After Taoiseach Leo Varadkar threatened to stall Brexit negotiations without guarantees on a hard border, Ireland seems pretty committed to the bloc.  However, as the impacts of Brexit on the EU become clearer, it’s likely Ireland will be one of the hardest-hit countries. If its economy is sunk by Britain leaving the trading bloc, Ireland could be the first country to follow us out of the Union.  In Hungary, Mr. Orbán's virulently anti-immigration party is no fan of European freedom of movement and has clashed with the EU leadership more than once.  He is set to win re-election later this year - which could give him the mandate to retreat from Europe.  Unsurprisingly, given its well-documented Euro woes, Greece tops the list of countries likely to be next to quit the EU.  https://www.express.co.uk/news/world/884279/Brexit-EU-European-countries-leave-bloc-follow-Britain-odds-favourites.   Poland is arguing with the EU over a controversial reform of its judiciary and in a recent poll, a third of those questioned said they rejected EU membership. https://www.dailyfx.com/forex/fundamental/article/special_report/2018/11/16/Which-Countries-Want-to-Leave-the-EU-After-Brexit-Euro-Analysis.html.  All of these predictions received a lot of attention in 2018- but look where Brexit is now.  TIME: Three years ago, Greece organized a referendum in just over a week, in which voters rejected the terms of an international bailout following the country's debt crisis- but experts assert that if referendums are organized too hastily, it can give the impression that "normal procedure is not being followed" and that voters may see the eventual result as illegitimate. So with respect to a timeframe- it is possible- especially as a new UK Brexit referendum is assessed to take at least 10 weeks to roll out.  So… is it possible by any country to set a referendum by 01 Jan 2020- YES; however, given that nationalism and isolationist trends have such a bad reputation today- and the UK demonstrated how divisive an EU exit can be- the probability of it happening is low.

The example of the United Kingdom will serve as a warning of the difficulties of exiting the EU, an example which can only become positive if, as happened when Henry VIII broke from the Papacy, the United Kingdom can make a success of its exit.

In order to judge if a state is likely to set a date for a Euro-skeptic referendum, we first have to examine whether or not a party that would be interested in such a course of events has the capability to do so. In the European union, so far there are only two countries with eurosceptic parties in a position to call for a referendum on leaving the EU: Denmark and Hungary. Formerly Sweden and France could also have been considered risk areas but recent elections have shown a relative turn to normalcy in the internal politics of those countries. However even in Norway and Hungary, we must consider the importance of internal politics. After the disaster of the U.K withdrawal process, a country is unlikely to proceed with a referendum call unless it can be sure that 
1. It can achieve a relatively popular level of support for a "leave EU" position
2. Calling for such a referendum isn't likely to endanger the party's own domestic political position and agenda as it has done with the Tories in the UK.
As rational actors within a state, right now the cards seem pretty handily stacked against the progression of a "leave EU" referendum in both Hungary and Denmark. In Hungary most citizens hold a neutral view of the EU, but more prefer the system than disdain it. And in Denmark the public has reacted strongly to the process of Brexit and support for the Union is at a high-water mark. This is not to say that it is impossible for a party to technically ram forward a referendum: however, as rational actors they likely realize to do so in this timeframe would be virtual political suicide. sources:
https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/brexit/2018/01/30/svexit-or-huxit-how-another-country-could-follow-the-uk-out-of-the-eu/
https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2016/06/23/these-countries-could-be-next-if-britain-leaves-the-e-u/?noredirect=on&utm_term=.d41f2cf78b8a
https://www.thelocal.dk/20190104/danish-eu-support-at-record-high-poll

Note of caution to myself and others: I’m very new to making thorough predictions, and I do not possess domain-specific knowledge about the EU (other than living in an EU country). Thus I have probably missed crucial information and/or included some irrelevant information. This prediction will be updated as I collect more information. Some conciderations: The base-rate of leaving EU seem to be fairly low, although I haven’t crunched the numbers yet, given that there are currently 28 member states of the EU, of which many of them became members in the 1990’s and mid 2000’s, and only the UK is on the path of exiting EU at the moment. Of course, Brexit might indicate a change in the underlying probability of member states leaving the EU; they might provoke other countries to leave the EU. However, the effect of Brexit on how citizens of EU countries view the EU have been positive it seems (https://www.pewglobal.org/2017/06/15/post-brexit-europeans-more-favorable-toward-eu/), i.e. there seem to have been an increase in the approval ratings for the EU between 2016 and 2017 (whether this is causal is unclear to me). But it is also clear that citizens of Greece look far less favourably on the EU than the UK (https://www.pewglobal.org/2017/06/15/post-brexit-europeans-more-favorable-toward-eu/), and the UK voted to leave. Thus there seem to be some risk that at least Greece would also exit the EU. The data I’m basing this on is roughly two years old, I’m therefore unsure how reliable it is as a predictor of the current sentiment. However, in the graph from the link cited above, Greek citizens seem to have had consistently lower approval of the EU than UK citizens since 2012. The reason not many experts seem to mention the risk of Greece exiting the EU is unclear to me at the moment, I will look into why that is in the future. The probability of exiting the eurozone might be somewhat independent from the probability of exiting the EU, so that states that exit the eurozone do not necessarily exit the EU. Only 19 of the 28 EU member states are part of the eurozone, which means the base rate for leaving the eurozone should probably be lower than for leaving the EU. As of yet, no countries have left the eurozone, and most member states entered it ~ 20 years ago, which should also push the probability downwards. All in all, I think this should increase the probability of the answer to the question being ”yes” by maybe 50% compared to only looking at the probability of a referendum on exiting the EU. Clarification: I’ve used the terms ”exiting EU” and ”exiting the eurozone” instead of ”setting a date for a referendum on exiting”. This is only to make the text readable; I do think the probability of setting a date is allmost by definition more likely than actually exiting, especially within a short time-frame. EDIT: I added some clarification.

I don't think this will happen. But the 5% consensus is crazy overconfident. There are 27 members of the EU. We hear about MAYBE 6 of them on the news regularly. Have people researched what's going on politically in Lithuania, or Malta? I sure haven't. When you say that there's a 95% chance that EVERY member will do X, implicitly you're saying each member has a 0.95^(1/27) ~ 99.8% chance of doing it. In other words, you're saying each EU member has only a 0.2% chance of scheduling a referendum. From a purely base rate standpoint, we don't have the data to make such a confident assertion about even the main, founding EU members such as Germany! The EU started 61 years ago, so after observing Germany not schedule a ref for 61 years, if we start from a no-info prior, by Bayes we should say there's a 1/63 ~ 1.6% chance they schedule it this year. If we adopt that level of confidence for all 27 countries, then we get a  1 - (1 - 0.016)^27 ~ 35% chance that at least one country schedules. One would also do well to remember that being in favor of a referendum is not the same as being in favor of leaving, see [1]: in mid-2017, only 22% of French wanted to leave, but 61% supported referendum. These numbers are 13% and 65% for Spain. Anywya, I don't think 35% is right either. We have info beyond base rates. I just did this calculation to illustrate how much confidence you need in your forecast for each country to justify a 5%/95% level of confidence in the aggregate result. Here are the EU countries, broken up into three groups: (1) No chance of scheduling ref this year:
Austria, Belgium, Ireland, Luxembourg, Germany, Netherlands, Portugal. (2) There have been at least some rumors of EU exit, and/or I know they are currently kind of unstable or disliking the EU:
Greece, Hungary, Italy, Poland, Sweden. (3) I don't know anything about them, or signal is noisy (is core member but people favor ref):
Bulgaria, Croatia, Republic of Cyprus, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Romania, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain. Let's say I give following odds: group 1, 0% chance of scheduling; group 2, each country has 1% chance of scheduling; group 3, 0.5%. Then odds that nobody schedules are (1.0^7)*(0.99^5)*(0.995)^15 ~ 88%. That means ~12% chance that one does. Will decrease by ~1% every month. [1] http://www.pewglobal.org/2017/06/15/post-brexit-europeans-more-favorable-toward-eu/

In examining this question, I divide the current EU members roughly into two groups: before and after 1996.  The first group includes the original members and most of western European and Scandinavian countries.  The second group consists of Eastern Europe and the Balkans. Greece and Italy are the most likely countries in the first group to have such a referendum.  Greece threatened to leave the Eurozone in the early 2000 during its debt crisis.  But it did not threaten to leave EU for the simple reason that it has more economic gain than loss staying in EU.  Italy is such a mess politically that it is unlikely that it has the consensus to act on exiting EU.   While there are minor rumblings from Eurosceptics in other countries in this group, they and their affiliated parties are not close to having much political power.  There is little chance that an EU-exit referendum will be declared in 2019 in this group.   Most of the countries in the second group used to be in the sphere of interest of the Soviet Union.  They do not have a long tradition of democracy and liberalism.  This leads to disagreements with EU (which is dominated by liberal democratic ideas and policies).  Talks of leaving EU arise as Eurosceptic parties gained power, such as in Hungary and Poland.  However, they have more to gain staying in EU than out.  These countries have received, and continue to receive, lots of funding for their economic development since they joined EU.  They are too small to be able to stand alone economically.   Talking of leaving is fine and useful in gaining leverage.  But they are not stupid enough to leave.  Furthermore, these countries seem to be able to thumb their nose at EU without consequence, such as putting up border fences to stop migrants.   After seeing the fiasco of Brexit (Cameron putting up a referendum for Brexit while believing that it would not pass), they will not even put up a referendum. Therefore I go out on a limb in forecasting 0%.

My previous forecast suggested this was very unlikely. However, after some additional thought I am seeing a lot of the same factors in lay as in GB. Populist sentiment, lagging economy, high debt, and immigration challenges (either real or perceived). GDP growth in the UK slowed in 2015 before the referendum was declared. Immigration from Syria and North Africa was picking up, and a Populist political party was elected. If I compare those three factors to my understanding of the current situation in Italy, the current situation for all 3 seems worse. Further, a recent study found 44% of Italian feel the EU has not been beneficial for their country. Further, 42% view membership as a "good thing" and 18% view it as a "bad thing". Now, the alternative argument. The Italian government is watching the challenges the UK is facing. Further, I think they understand the trade benefits EU membership provides. Finally, I would argue that as one of the weaker EU economies, Italy would be the first to fall into a recession (third in the past 15 years). Leaving in a weak economic environment, with a depreciating currency, and little room to cut rates would be detrimental. The budget is technically in alignment with EU rules, I think this is saber-rattling. So let's come to a probability. Economics rarely play in the voting booth and austerity plays less. That would push me towards an increase in probability (by say 20%). However, the recession fears are real and I have to believe Italy doesn't want to go through "Brexit" in a negative growth environment (-7 to -10%). Ultimately, the question is whether a referendum will be scheduled - something the ruling party might do for political cover (+3 to +7%). I'll settle at 17%

The phrasing of this question is key. To decipher it:
- The number of states increases the chances (it will only take 1 state from 27 to make the answer 'yes').
- The question stipulates announcing a date for a referendum. The announcement must happen in 2019. The date of the referendum is irrelevant. 
- The referendum does not have to pass or even occur! It merely has to be announced this year.  Looking at % of far-right parties in each countries parliament might also not give a good indicator. The British referendum was called by a moderate, pro-EU, centre-right politician in a centre-right party. The UK then only had a tiny populist party (UKIP).    So although the event is unlikely it is not impossible. I'll revise my 5% down as time elapses unless something unusual happens.

Although many countries have minority eurosceptic parties, no EU country currently has a government which wants a referendum AFAIK. When the UK voted to leave in 2016, British citizens had a -5% positive/negative view of the EU, in other words 5% more Brits had a negative view of the EU than a positive one [1 - page 16]. Only two countries currently have a net negative view of the EU [2 - page 10]; Greece (10% net negative) and the Czech Republic (4% net negative). Greece has a general election in 2019 but neither of the two main parties want a referendum. The Czech Republic had a general election in 2017 which formed a broadly pro-European coalition government but with concerns about specific issues eg. immigration. Although Poland and Hungary are often described as having eurosceptic governments, there are many flavours of euroscepticism and neither country has a government that wants to actually leave the EU. Citizens of both countries are very net positive with regard to the EU; Hungarians are 24% net positive and Poles are 44% net positive. EDIT 10 Jan 2019
I forgot Italy. The current Italian government is often characterised as being anti-EU, implying that it wants to take Italy out of the EU but that's wrong. Most Italians are pro-EU but anti-Eurozone. Officially the coalition government wants to stay in both the EU and the Eurozone. Five Star are sincere, but Lega's leader Salvini is not. Salvini's past statements over several years reveal that he would love to see the end of the Eurozone, however he doesn't say that in public (any more) because he knows it's a vote loser. He has changed tactics and is now forming an anti-EU European Parliamentary party to attack the EU from within. EU Parliament elections are 23-26 May 2019. Despite the ongoing fiasco of Brexit probably being interpreted as a cautionary tale, I think that the current crowd estimate on this (1% as of 5 January) is far too conservative considering the major challenges coming down the track for the EU over the medium-term future.    Among others: the as-yet-unresolved issues with the Euro,  the ongoing centre-periphery tensions on issues of fiscal/monetary/regulatory independence and culture wars,  the rise of populism and fracturing of 'old guard' establishment parties during the many elections due this year,  the continued erosion of industrial and demographic stability,  the brewing unrest in the Balkans,   the creeping revanchism and strategic provocations by Russia,  not to mention the global economy being overdue another recession (with all the associated ECB-Member State pressures seen after 2008). On balance I think that an exit referendum somewhere in the EU in 2019 is unlikely (although the 2020s are another matter), but the current weight of the consensus against a referendum is far too complacent about the many potential crises and electoral crunch points which are already in train.

From Parlemeter 2018 (http://www.europarl.europa.eu/at-your-service/files/be-heard/eurobarometer/2018/parlemeter-2018/report/en-parlemeter-2018.pdf), 6 countries responded to the question "Generally speaking,, do you think that (our country's) membership of the EU is a bad thing" in more than 15%, one of the the UK. The other candidates: Romania, Greece, Italy, Czech Republic and Austria, with Eurosceptic governments in Greece and Italy. This will be a quite interesting year:
On the one hand everyone sees exactly how messy withdrawing will become, on the other hand there is significant friction within the EU and within several countries within the EU. From the top of my head I know of Poland, Hungary, Italy and Greece which have active conflicts with Brussels. If we end up in the next economic crisis it is likely that at least Spain will also end up breaching budget rules and creating a new conflict. The main point why I think it is (still) unlikely is that the final result of Brexit still won't be in. Either we have a hard Brexit, then it will be an excellent study case on exactly how interconnected Europe is today and exactly how pragmatic governments will end up being in the face of actual crisis. But the long-term relationship won't be finalised at the end of this year and probably be highly in flux. Or we get some kind of deal (somewhere between TM's deal and staying in the EU) in which case we will probably have a somewhat good idea of how the future relationship will look like, but still nothing finalised. I'm uncertain what the extend of "leave-willingness" really is in even these EU member states. I have a certain amount of hope that it is mainly posturing in order to get a better negotiating position, rather than a primary leave wish. But as this was precisely the reasoning behind Mr. Cameron's calling of the referendum that offers only limited optimism. Starting with 15% which is probably high, but in a world with DJT I'm erring on the side of uncertainty.
